awd_titl_txt: Optimal Transport, Interacting Particles, and Stochastic Portfolio Theory
awd_abstract_narration:
The practical motivation for the questions under study in this research project comes from quantitative finance. Specifically, the project investigates the mathematics behind portfolios that outperform a standard index such as S&P 500 in the presence of volatility. The utility of such portfolios is that in that process they reduce volatility demonstrably, and thus contribute to the stability of financial markets. Although ad hoc use of such portfolios is widespread, a systematic mathematical study has been limited so far. It turns out the mathematics is related to some very modern topics in probability and geometry, especially that of the Monge-Kantorovich optimal transport maps. Successful completion of the research will not only lead to striking new mathematics in probability and information geometry, but will also imply very practical applications in modern portfolio management, with potential societal benefits of the highest level via increased financial stability. 

The investigator plans to study an array of problems linking the fields of optimal transport and interacting particle systems, with applications to modern portfolio theory. There are two parts to this project. The first one investigates the behavior of exponential stochastic integrals where the integrand is given by a solution of a Monge-Kantorovich optimal transport map. The study is an interesting interplay between geometry of the unit simplex and universal behavior of stochastic integrals when they are not martingales. Classical probability relies heavily on the martingale property of stochastic integrals. Here, the investigator explores a completely distinct class of behaviors that should be of independent interest. The second part studies properties of interacting continuous-time particle systems in finite and infinite dimensions. These particle systems, originally coming from stochastic portfolio theory, can be thought of as a continuous-time analogue of the discrete time exclusion process on the integer lattice. However, unlike exclusion processes, very little is known about these processes. They are conjectured to display striking phase transitions. The project aims to establish concentration inequalities and fluctuation estimates (among other properties) for such processes, which is a step towards proving more subtle behavior of these processes.

por.por_cntn:
INTELLECTUAL MERIT: The goal of this project was to connect the modern mathemtical field Monge-Kantorovich optimal transport with the practical problem of constructing actively traded stock portfolios that outperform a passive stock market index. In economics, it is widely believed and observed phenomenon that a well-diversified market portfolio (i.e., index funds) tend to outperform activaley traded stock portfolios in the long run. However, in the late 1990s and early 2000s, Robert Fernholz exhibit portfolios that, under certain realistic conditions, can outperform the market portfolio, irrespective of the future market behavior. Our investigation confirms his findings and show that there is only a narrow class of such portfolios that exist which are given as solutions of a mathematical area that arose out of geometry and economics of optimal allocation, called the Monge-Kantorovich optimal transport problem. Not only this is an unexpected connection, it also introduces a new mathematical problem in the optimal transport literature that has remarkable geometric properties. There were a few other major problems that were funded by this grant. One of those was the construction of the so-called Aldous diffusion, named after the famous probabilist David Aldous who first conjectured its existence. The problem is on the random time evolution of large combinatorial trees, such an evolutionary tree. A statistician who wishes to model an evolutionary tree based on DNA data of various organisms would typically run a Markov Chain Monte Carlo algorithm to fit her model. Such an algorithm, starting from an intial tree, would make small random changes to the tree structure to look for a better fit. This creates a stochastic process on very large trees. The Aldous diffusion arises as the limit of such an evolution as the tree size goes to infinity. One is interested in such limiting behavior since they tend to be 'universal', that is, the exact details of the specific problem do not matter and the statistical analysis is robust. Along we collaborators we confirmed the existence of the conjectured process and worked out many of its amazing properties resolving this twenty year old conjecture. 

 

BROADER IMPACT: These projects have resulted in several research papers and supported thesis work of three agraduate students. It also supported the work of a postdoctoral scholar. The work on portfolio theory has been adapted by industry researchers who have analyzed their own data using our theory and integrated their findings in their products. The PI ahs widely traveled across the world and spoke in several conferences, sumemr schools, and seminars disseminating the findings.
